weaknesses: Ferry access adds travel complexity and cost
Weather can be wet and challenging
No significant prestige or competitive depth
Fondo format may not appeal to pure racers

beats.label: THE NUMBERS DON'T LIE
beats.narration: The data doesn't care about your feelings. Altitude. 1 out of 5. Oxygen plentiful. Power output normal. Campbell River sits at sea level and forest roads stay low throughout the route to Campbell Lake. Prestige. 2 out of 5. Regional reputation. The locals know. Part of Trek BC Gravel Series drawing strong provincial participation - 178 riders in 2024 growing to 216 in 2025. Field Depth. 2 out of 5. Enough competition to keep you honest. Michael Van Den Ham's 3:16:10 Esperto win and Sofia Donnecke's 3:59:27 women's time show solid competitive depth.
beats.visual: Score cards — lowest 3 dimensions with explanations
beats.editing_note: RE-ENGAGEMENT BEAT — this is the ~2 min mark. Start with the least bad score, escalate to worst. Each score reveal: brief silence (0.5s), then number slams in. Avatar reaction scales with how bad the score is. Von Restorff: visually isolate the worst score (different color, bigger text, longer hold). [RIFF HERE] after the worst score reveal.

beats.label: THE BOTTOM LINE
beats.narration: If you're on Vancouver Island or want an excuse to visit, this is a solid gravel fondo with good terrain and organization. The ferry logistics and weather uncertainty are the main barriers. For BC residents, it's a worthwhile regional event. For travelers from afar, probably not worth the trip unless you're combining it with island tourism.
beats.editing_note: PAYOFF. Close the open loop from the hook. Avatar delivers final take directly to camera. End ABRUPTLY — never signal 'we're wrapping up.' MrBeast rule: cut to CTA mid-energy.
